Base64 Encoding:

Base64 is a data encoding scheme. Base64 encoding converts group of bytes into a sequence of readable ASCII characters.

Base64 breaks the bytes(8 bits) into groups of 6 bits. Each 6 bits group is mapped to a character. This character is
one of the 64 characters in the Base64 character table. These characters include a-z, A-Z, 0-9, +, / and a special
purpose character =(The 65th character).

Padding =


Base64 takes byte sequence and divide them to groups of 6 bits. Sometimes it's impossible to divide the sequence into
exact number of groups of 6 bits. In this case, 0 will be padded into the sequence so that it will be exact number of
groups of 24 bits(least common multiple of 6 and 8). This process is called padding.

When encoding the padded data, if there are 6 bits group fully padded(each bit in the group is padded without containing
any bit from the original data), it will be mapped to "="
